_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
 

A.  It is the policy of the Archer Daniels Midland Company (ADM) Corn Processing Facility, Marshall, Minnesota, to implement the requirements of the Risk Management Program (RMP) in accordance with the USEPA regulations under 40 CFR Part 68.  The objective is to prevent an explosion/fire or release of chlorine or anhydrous sulfur dioxide and in the unlikely event of a release to minimize the potential impact to ADM?s employees, the public, and the environment.  This objective will be accomplished by utilizing good operating procedures, maintaining a preventative maintenance program, providing appropriate training to employees, and coordinating response activities, as necessary with the Marshall Fire Department and Lyon County Emergency Planning and Advisory Committee.  


B.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled
This facility consists of a Corn Wet Milling plant that processes corn into value added products such as corn sweeteners, fuel ethanol, and dry specialty products. 

In this update of the Risk Management Plan, ADM has included programs for its denaturant used in the production of fuel ethanol.  The denaturant (natural gasoline) used at the facilities generally has a National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) flammability hazard rating of less than 4 and is exempt from the RMP according to 40 CFR 68.115(b)(2).  However, due to the potential variability in the makeup of this additive, it is possible that ADM could receive material that has a flammability rating of 4.  Therefore, ADM has included provisions in the Risk Management Plan for managing the denaturant as a precautionary measure.  

Therefore, the regulated substances used at this facility are chlorine, anhydrous sulfur dioxide and pentane (n-pentane & 1-pentane).  Chlorine is used as a bacterial inhibitor in process cooling water.  Anhydrous sulfur dioxide is used as a processing aid as well as a bacterial inhibitor.  n-pentane & 1-pentane are components of the n

atural gasoline used in the denaturant for fuel ethanol production.


C.  Off-Site Consequence Analysis
To perform the required offsite consequence analysis, ADM used the look-up tables and equations provided by the EPA in the RMP*COMP version 1.07. 

Worst-Case Scenario Toxic Substances: For multiple toxic substances subject to Program 3 requirements, the EPA requires that a worst-case scenario be evaluated for the toxic substance estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to an endpoint. The worst-case scenario for substances that are normally gases at ambient temperatures but are liquefied by pressure assumes that the single largest container fails catastrophically and the entire contents are released as a gas over a ten-minute period resulting in offsite impacts.  The worst-case scenario for this facility involves a catastrophic release from an anhydrous sulfur dioxide above ground tank stored on site.  Safe handling procedures, work practices and the safety devices inherent in the design of the containers make this scenario extremely unlikely.

Alternative Scenario: EPA requires that one alternative scenario, or more realistic scenario, be evaluated for each toxic substance.  EPA also requires that each alternative scenario result in off-site impacts, if such a scenario exists.  

A more realistic release scenario involving n-pentane & 1-pentane would be a break in the line supplying liquid denaturant from the storage tank to the process, or a storage tank leak.  

A more realistic release scenario involving anhydrous sulfur dioxide would also be a break in the line supplying liquid sulfur dioxide from the storage tank to the process.  No active or passive mitigation measures were considered for this scenario.

A more realistic release scenario for chlorine involves the rupture of the flexible connections (pigtails) connected to a one-ton container. No active or passive mitigation measures were considered for this scenario.

Worst-Case Scenario

Flammable Substances:  For multiple flammable substances subject to Program 3 requirements, the EPA requires that a worst-case scenario be evaluated for the flammable substance estimated to create the greatest distance in any direction to an endpoint. The worst-case scenario for substances that are normally liquids at ambient temperatures assumes that the single largest container fails catastrophically and the entire contents are released.  The worst-case scenario for this facility involves a catastrophic release from a denaturant (natural gasoline) storage tank, resulting in a vapor cloud explosion (endpoint is overpressure of 1 pound per square inch).  Safe handling procedures, work practices and the fire-protection system makes this scenario extremely unlikely.

A more realistic release scenario involving n-pentane & 1-pentane would be a break in the line supplying liquid denaturant from the storage tank to the process, or a storage tank leak.  This liquid leak would be contained via the secondary containment dike surrounding the storage tank, or via excess flow checks within the process piping. 




D.  Accidental Release Prevention
The key concepts in this facility's prevention programs are the elements of OSHA?s Process Safety Management Program under 29 CFR 1910.119, which all of this facility?s RMP processes are subject to.  These concepts include: employee participation, analysis of hazards, operating procedures and safe work practices, personnel training, maintenance and mechanical integrity programs, and contractor programs.  


E.  Five-Year Accident History
This facility has not had any accidents involving chlorine, anhydrous sulfur dioxide or pentane that require reporting under EPA?s Risk Management Rule.


F.  Emergency Response Program
Emergency response at this facility is coordinated with ADM personnel and the LEPC and/or City of Marshall Fire Department so that in the event of an accident, immediate emergency response measures will be implemented

.  The facility maintains a written Environmental/Emergency Response Plan to deal with prevention of and response to accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The facility is also an active member of the Lyon County Local Emergency Planning Committee.


G.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety
As a result of a safety review of this facility's chlorine, and anhydrous sulfur dioxide systems the following changes were made to improve safety.  An chlorine detection system has been installed and is functional.  A sulfur dioxide detection system is in the process of being installed and calibrated.  There were also several recommended actions that were completed as a result of the process hazard analyses.  

ADM will continue to evaluate and implement changes when necessary to improve safety at the Marshall facility.
